posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: Our team used two Limelight cameras this year—one for April tags (LL3G) and one "standard" LL3 used for pole detection. Each camera was connected to an aux port on our radio via CAT6 cabling. Without using POE or other Ethernet equipment, we didn't need an additional switch. Occasionally (about 5% of the time), either camera failed to establish Ethernet communication. The blinking LEDs on both the radio and camera ports stayed off during these instances. Restarting the camera by cycling its power or simply unplugging and replugging the Ethernet cable restored communication. It was notable that reconnecting the cable took roughly the same time as performing a full power cycle on the camera. Have you experienced this issue before? Could there be something specific regarding NT4 connections we're overlooking?

posts.name: Clayton Colburn
posts.cooked: We encountered a similar issue where approximately 50% of the time, one of our two limelights wouldn’t connect on the field. We attempted various solutions, including both POE and non-POE configurations, as well as automatic and static IP settings, but none proved effective. The only resolution was introducing a network switch. Based on this experience, we concluded that the Aux ports on the new radios are not reliably suited for limelight connections.

We struggled with this issue throughout the year. At Curie, the head of FTA (FIRST Technical Advisor) told us it was Limelights' fault because they boot too slowly for the RoboRio, which only hands out IP addresses for a limited time. (This has not been verified personally.)  
This problem presented itself as a dead port on the VH-109 because no lights would blink on the “dead” port.  
After a reboot, it was almost always resolved.

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: The added network switch would still have needed to be connected to one of the auxiliary ports on the radio, correct? This is because it must be able to communicate with the RIO, which itself needs to be plugged into the RIO port of the radio.

posts.name: Clayton Colburn
posts.cooked: You would connect Roborio to the switch and then connect the switch to the Rio port on the radio.

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked:
EXTREMELY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. The text is:

Thanks. I thought it was required that RoboRIO had to be plugged directly into radio, but I must be mistaken. We also battled what seemed to be slow vision position updates occasionally (only during autonomous running pathplanner paths, and ONLY when connected to the field). I wonder if adding the switch would have helped us out with that. But all I can do is wonder now … until next season. Thanks for input.

posts.name: Casey Stahl - 2358 - Robot Repairman (Mentor)
posts.cooked:
We also had those issues, but far more frequently. Additionally, there was the problem with the lighting at WI. We had to restart the robot multiple times, sometimes even three times during a match. We made sure to power it up 20 seconds before the previous match ended to give ourselves enough time to reset it if needed. I also checked the cable every time, though that didn’t seem to be the issue.

Ultimately, we brought a tag to test if the camera could detect it, with our technician either giving us a thumbs-up or a signal to power cycle it if it failed. This whole situation was frustrating and something we rarely repeated in the pit. Last year, issues with an Ethernet switch prevented us from adding one again.

posts.name: Dylan Li
posts.cooked: Was this issue only present on FMS?

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: In my team’s case, no. It was pretty much 5% of the time regardless of where we were—on the field or at home. We had to put all new cabling in twice. This issue happened with about the same frequency on two different cameras.

posts.name: Dylan Li
posts.cooked: Is your RIO configured to have a Static IP? We had an issue last year with our LimeLight not connecting to our RIO during competitions. It was not resolved and we switched to Photon Vision this season, but we noticed that the Photon Vision documentation recommends a static IP for the RIO, which we did not set up last year for the LimeLight.
We had this issue as well with static IPs configured on both of our Limelights. A reboot consistently fixed the issue.

posts.name: 4391 Programming Mentor
posts.cooked: I feel like a dummy, but I don’t know offhand about the RIO. I assumed that setting the team number on the RIO would assign a static IP address, such as 10.xx.xx.2. Are there additional steps required to confirm it’s a static IP? Both our lightboards are configured with static IPs.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: You would connect Roborio to the switch and then connect the switch to the Rio port on the radio. This is an illegal configuration per R703.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: When this issue occurred, were you able to view the camera feed when accessing the Limelight directly via a web browser? Sometimes, links may not work properly, or the content might be cached incorrectly. Accessing Limelight directly through a web browser might result in slow loading times, broken images, or connectivity problems. Ensuring your browser has the necessary plugins for viewing video feeds is also important. If none of these technical issues resolve the problem, try accessing the feed through a dedicated application. Additionally, verify that your device has sufficient bandwidth for smooth video playback. Confirming whether there was a problem with the camera feed when accessing Limelight via a web browser is crucial. Slow website loading can affect video display, which might be due to a poor internet connection or outdated browser versions. Enabling JavaScript is essential for streaming media. Clearing the browser cache or using an incognito window might bypass cache issues. Checking for server downtime or maintenance on the Limelight-hosted server and verifying browser compatibility with Limelight’s technology are also important considerations. It might help to know if others are experiencing similar issues. If none of these steps work, contacting Limelight’s customer support would be the appropriate next step.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.name: Clayton Colburn
posts.cooked: The R703 must use a specific Ethernet port, which should be connected either directly to the "RIO" bridge port labeled for VH-109 radios or to the "18-24v POE" port for OpenMesh radios. The connection can be made directly, through a network switch, or via a CAT5 Ethernet pigtail.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: When using OpenMesh radios, the power requirement is typically "18-24v P OE," which can be supplied directly, through a network switch, via an RPM (Revolutions Per Minute) measurement, or via a CAT5 Ethernet pigtail. This method applies specifically to the OMP5 model, which is still commonly used in China and Taiwan.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.cooked: There is currently no connectivity. No data is populated in NT, and there is no web stream available.

posts.name: Fletcher
posts.cooked: Including no web config interface for the limelight when attempting to access it at its static IP (For example, did the web interface open, but with no camera stream?, Were you able to ping the Limelight?)

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST California | FTAA, CSA, A/V, and everything between.

posts.cooked: We were not able to ping the static IP or hostname, and the web interface was entirely inaccessible. It was as if the Limelight wasn’t attached to the robot.

posts.name: Jared Russell
posts.cooked: We also faced intermittent connection issues with Limelight 4 upon starting the system. Rebooting the robot typically resolved these issues. We employed static IPs, updated firmware, and initially set the gateway to both x.1 (as per documentation) and x.4 (later confirmed as correct).
